description.title: Sample from Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655

organism.organismName: Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655

assemblyInfo.comments:
This is a project to identify additional regulators of FtsZ in E. coli.

Bacteria provided by Petra A. Levin, PhD (Department of Biology, Washington University in St. Louis, One Brookings Drive, St. Louis MO 63130, USA). DNA from E. coli MC4100 leu::Tn10-ftsZ84 acquired from Jonathan Beckwith, PhD (Department of Microbiology and Immunobiology, Harvard Medical School, 200 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA 02155, USA) was transduced into E. coli K12 MG1655 to introduce the ftsZ84 allele to the MG1655 background. Funded by Spatial Control of B. subtilis Cytokinesis (NIH GM064671).
Source DNA provided by Heidi Arjes (Department of Biology, Washington University in St. Louis, One Brookings Drive, St. Louis MO 63130) and Darina Cejkova (The Genome Institute, Washington University School of Medicine, Campus Box 8501, 4444 Forest Park Blvd, Saint Louis, MO 63108)

sampleIds.value: Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655

description.title: Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655 (Migula) Castellani and Chalmers (ATCC 47076)

organism.organismName: Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655

assemblyInfo.comments:
The annotation was added by the NCBI Prokaryotic Genome Annotation Pipeline (PGAP). Information about PGAP can be found here: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genome/annotation_prok/
These genomes were assembled using Linked Read technology (similar to 10X Genomics), where DNA fragments (300-500bp) originating from the same molecular sequence (10-50KB) are tagged with the same barcode sequence. The ends of each DNA fragment (300-500bp) are sequenced as Pairs, along with the barcode tag.

description.title: Sample from Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655

organism.organismName: Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655

assemblyInfo.comments:
This is a project to identify additional regulators of FtsZ in E. coli.

Bacteria provided by Petra A. Levin, PhD (Department of Biology, Washington University in St. Louis, One Brookings Drive, St. Louis MO 63130, USA). DNA from E. coli MC4100 leu::Tn10-ftsZ84 acquired from Jonathan Beckwith, PhD (Department of Microbiology and Immunobiology, Harvard Medical School, 200 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA 02155, USA) was transduced into E. coli K12 MG1655 to introduce the ftsZ84 allele to the MG1655 background. Funded by Spatial Control of B. subtilis Cytokinesis (NIH GM064671).
Source DNA provided by Heidi Arjes (Department of Biology, Washington University in St. Louis, One Brookings Drive, St. Louis MO 63130) and Darina Cejkova (The Genome Institute, Washington University School of Medicine, Campus Box 8501, 4444 Forest Park Blvd, Saint Louis, MO 63108)

description.title: Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655 (Migula) Castellani and Chalmers (ATCC 47076)

organism.organismName: Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655

assemblyInfo.comments:
The annotation was added by the NCBI Prokaryotic Genome Annotation Pipeline (PGAP). Information about PGAP can be found here: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genome/annotation_prok/
These genomes were assembled using Linked Read technology (similar to 10X Genomics), where DNA fragments (300-500bp) originating from the same molecular sequence (10-50KB) are tagged with the same barcode sequence. The ends of each DNA fragment (300-500bp) are sequenced as Pairs, along with the barcode tag.
